title: 115_hr2834
content: The Act is titled the "Partnership Grants to Strengthen Families Affected by Parental Substance Abuse Act." It enhances grants to improve the well-being of families affected by substance abuse. Section 437(f) of the Social Security Act is amended to implement IV-E Prevention Services and improve well-being and permanency outcomes for children and families affected by heroin, opioids, and other substances. It defines a regional partnership as a collaborative agreement involving mandatory partners for all partnership grants. The State child welfare agency and the State agency responsible for substance abuse prevention are mandatory partners for partnership grants. If serving children in out-of-home placements, the Juvenile Court or Administrative Office of the Court must oversee the administration. The partnership grants require the oversight of court programs in the region to address families involved in child abuse or neglect. Optional partners can include Indian tribes, nonprofit and for-profit child welfare providers, community health and mental health providers, local law enforcement, and school personnel. The partnership grants involve oversight of court programs in the region to address child abuse or neglect, with optional partners like Indian tribes, child welfare providers, health providers, law enforcement, and school personnel. Indian tribes or tribal consortia in regional partnerships are not required to include the State child welfare agency as a partner. In collaborative agreements for partnership grants, the State child welfare agency must be included, tribal child welfare agencies cannot be the sole partners, and tribal court organizations can be included instead of other judicial partners. The funding range has been adjusted to be between $250,000 and $1,000,000, with a focus on planning for approval. The grant awarded under this subsection shall be disbursed in two phases: a planning phase not exceeding 2 years and an implementation phase. The total disbursement for the planning phase may not exceed $250,000. The grant awarded under this subsection is disbursed in two phases: a planning phase not exceeding 2 years and an implementation phase. No payment shall be made until the Secretary determines sufficient progress in meeting grant goals and coordination among partnership members. No payment shall be made until the Secretary determines sufficient progress in meeting grant goals and coordination among partnership members. The current chunk focuses on improving substance abuse treatment outcomes for parents and facilitating the implementation, delivery, and effectiveness of prevention programs. The current chunk revises the requirements for sustaining services after the grant period, including utilizing prevention services and other funds for child welfare and substance abuse programs. The revised requirements for sustaining services after the grant period include demonstrating successful collaboration among child welfare, substance abuse treatment, and mental health agencies. The paragraph discusses the revision of indicators related to child safety, parental recovery, parenting capacity, and family well-being in grants for child welfare, substance abuse treatment, and mental health agencies. In revising indicators for grants in child welfare, substance abuse treatment, and mental health agencies, performance measures should be based on lessons learned from prior rounds of regional partnership grants. Other stakeholders or constituencies may be included as determined by the Secretary. Semiannual reports are required by September 30 of each fiscal year. The grant recipient must submit a report to the Secretary every 6 months detailing services provided, progress towards program goals, and the number of individuals served. The report due by September 30 of the final fiscal year must include data on performance indicators. The grant recipient must submit a report every 6 months detailing services provided, progress towards program goals, and the number of individuals served, including data on performance indicators for the evaluation of the regional partnership. The effective date for the program implementation is outlined in Section 3. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2017, with a transition rule for State plans under part B of title IV of the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2017, with a transition rule for State plans under part B of title IV of the Social Security Act. In the case of a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session. For Indian tribal organizations needing time to comply with the Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide necessary assistance. The Secretary will provide additional time for tribes, organizations, or tribal consortiums to comply with new requirements before being considered non-compliant. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 20, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
